title: SoftBank rides Asia tech bonanza to record profit
text:
Hi all — James here in Hong Kong. What a difference a year makes. The headlines about SoftBank in 2020 were often gloomy but today the Japanese company could surpass Microsoft to become the third most profitable company in the world. SoftBank's success is largely a reflection of Asia's tech boom (The Big Story). Also, don't miss how Coinbase's blockbuster IPO is energising Asia's crypto scene. Take care till next week.

The Big Story — Exclusive

SoftBank is riding Asia's tech bonanza to record profits. The world's biggest tech investor was set to announce an annual net profit of about $45bn on Wednesday (after #techAsia went to press), in what would be a record haul by a Japanese company, according to this exclusive in Nikkei Asia.

Its extraordinary performance was partly down to two blockbuster initial public offerings by portfolio companies: South Korea ecommerce business Coupang and food delivery group DoorDash of the US, which raised $4.6bn and $3.37bn respectively. Huge payouts such as these may continue.

Key implications: SoftBank has been riding Asia's tech boom. Grab, the Singapore-based “super app” and another SoftBank portfolio company, is planning to go public on Nasdaq in the coming months after completing a $40bn Spac merger.

Other important portfolio companies are planning similar moves. Chinese ride-hailing group Didi Chuxing, is preparing an IPO in the US that looks set to value the company at $70bn-$100bn. Tokopedia, the Indonesian ecommerce company, is also planning to raise capital. China's ByteDance has postponed plans to go public but remains part of SoftBank's longer term pipeline.

Upshot: SoftBank's record profits would mark a sharp turnround from its previous annual earnings. Whether the bonanza will last depends to a great extent on stock market valuations. The sell-off in tech stocks as inflation fears stalk the markets suggests potential turbulence ahead.

Mercedes' top 10

  1. Nintendo's Switch gaming console has become a casualty of the global chip shortage. (FT)

  2. Don't miss this excellent Big Read co-authored by James on China's space ambitions and President Xi Jinping's vision of being “a space power in all respects”. (FT)

  3. Nio, the Chinese electric vehicle company that was facing near ruin last year, reckons it is going to sell vehicles in Norway from September. (Nikkei Asia)

  4. South Korea's Samsung, the world's biggest chipmaker, is unlikely to have its leadership challenged anytime soon. But it has fallen behind Taiwanese rival TSMC in cutting edge technology. (NA)

  5. Here's a sign of the times. Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing is breaking with a tradition of focusing on the US, Europe and Israel and investing in Indonesia. (Bloomberg)

  6. Optimism about electric vehicles provided a big boost to SK IE Technology, the battery materials affiliate of SK Innovation, in its stock market debut in Seoul. (NA)

  7. A Nikkei survey demonstrates China's stalled progress in advanced semiconductor technology. Most respondents said US sanctions were hindering progress. (NA)

  8. Shares in Pinduoduo and Meituan plunged after the Chinese tech groups were rebuked for their business practices. Elsewhere, edtech unicorns Zuoyebang and Yuanfudao were slapped with fines. (FT, SCMP)

  9. I wrote about how Singapore has introduced strict age limits to curb the number of young drivers taking up ride-hailing as a job. (FT)

  10. How well can AI understand your emotions? Take the FT's Instagram test. My face was expressive 58 per cent of the time and I don't like cats. (FT)

When sages speak

  • Really interesting podcast here on Tesla's Elon Musk and his strategy in China. Thanks to Jordan Schneider, host of the ChinaTalk podcast, and his guest Kevin Xu of the Interconnected newsletter.

  • This research from several authors at Oxford university shows how Chinese diplomats artificially amplify their voices on Twitter. Taking China's former ambassador to the UK as an example, the researchers found that inauthentic Twitter accounts were responsible for 44 per cent of the diplomat's retweets.

  • Nisa Leung, Managing Partner of Qiming Venture Partners, makes some interesting points about investing in the region in this interview with James for the Collision technology conference.

Our take

A Chinese poem written more than 1,000 years ago was implicated in an almost 12 per cent drop in the share price of a food delivery company this week.

The reach of Chinese history is long indeed. But there are more contemporary lessons to learn from the travails of Meituan, even beyond the obvious point that companies in China may be well advised to employ “chief poetry officers”.

The sell-off occurred after Wang Xing, Meituan's CEO, posted — and then quickly deleted — a verse from Zhang Jie, a Tang dynasty poet. One line, in translation, reads: “The ashes of burnt books had not yet faded away but the Qin dynasty was already weak.”

This may be esoteric to many outside China but it was shared more than 32m times on Weibo, the blogging platform, and was widely seen as a veiled criticism of the Chinese leadership. Wang's 11 per cent stake in the company is estimated to have lost about $1bn in value because of his poetic flourish.

If the verse was indeed a veiled criticism, it may have been taking aim at an official investigation into the conditions endured by Meituan's delivery drivers and a more overarching anti-monopoly crackdown on Chinese big tech.

— James

Spotlight

Coinbase's blockbuster stock market listing has fired the starting gun on a pile into cryptocurrencies. In Asia, there is already plenty of action, especially with Hong Kong and Singapore having introduced regulatory sandboxes to test crypto-related rules. The challenge for many start-ups is navigating a complex regulatory environment says Flex Yang, co-founder of Hong Kong-based Babel Finance.

That's partly why his crypto financial services company has just raised $40m from investors including New York-based Tiger Global Management as well as German media conglomerate Bertelsmann and its Asia-focused investment arm BAI Capital. The deal is the first such investment in Asia's crypto finance industry for both groups.

Yang says it is less about needing capital — Babel Finance is “very profitable” with strong cash flows. What the company — and many other young crypto companies — require is investors that can provide connections and credibility for growth. “The more institutional investors participate in the market, the less volatile it will be,” Yang said.

Art of the deal

We got news this week from Gojek, Indonesia's biggest private technology start-up but it wasn't the megamerger deal that some might have anticipated. The “super app” has bagged $300m in new funding from state-owned mobile operator Telkomsel. The new funds are part of Telkomsel's agreement with the tech company when it invested $150m in November, which included an option to inject more money at a later date.

That said, this will probably be Gojek's final fundraising before it completes its merger with Tokopedia. The deal, which is expected to value the merged entity at about $18bn and could be completed as early as next month, would be the biggest merger between two start-ups in south-east Asia's largest economy.

Telkomsel's additional investment could provide the Indonesian mobile operator with a substantial windfall. Gojek and Tokopedia are planning to go public once the merger is finalised and are aiming for a valuation close to the $40bn that Gojek's rival Grab announced when it unveiled plans last month to go public via a Spac.

Smart data

A new trend is sweeping Taiwan: stocks. A record 670,000 people opened share-trading accounts last year, according to the Taiwan Stock Exchange. Almost half of the population is investing in shares and nearly half of last year's new accounts were opened by people under 30. The main beneficiary of this shift? Taiwan's chip companies. Shares in TSMC, United Microelectronics, Nanya Technology and MediaTek are on a tear.
